figure_1.title: Figure 1.
figure_1.caption: The Mara area, showing the MMNR, the surrounding group ranches and conservancies. Our study area focused on Koyiaki Group Ranch which is made up of the Mara North, Olare Motorogi and Naboisho Conservancies, and surrounding community areas shown in white

figure_2.title: Figure 2.
figure_2.caption: DRSRS 5 × 5 km2 sampling units inside and outside conservancies in Koyiaki Group Ranch

figure_3.title: Figure 3.
figure_3.caption: Contribution of different livelihood activities to total annual household income (%)

figure_4.title: Figure 4.
figure_4.caption: Proportion of gross annual household income from different activities, disaggregated into conservancy members (n = 127) and non-member (n = 121) households

figure_7.title: Figure 7.
figure_7.caption: Trends in cattle and shoat populations in the Mara ecosystem from 1977 to 2014

figure_8.title: Figure 8.
figure_8.caption: Trends in cattle and shoat density, inside and outside of conservancies, 1977 to 2014, Koyiaki Group Ranch. Figure note: Coral circles and solid lines denote inside conservancies and forest green triangles and dashed trend lines outside conservancies. The dashed blue line indicates when conservancies began to expand in number and size in 2006

claims.sentence:
Results can inform better future conservation and tourism investments aimed at maintaining and enhancing pastoral resilience, as well as promoting wildlife conservation.Study area
The Mara comprises the Maasai Mara National Reserve (MMNR) and surrounding conservancies and group ranches (Figure 1).
From an initial two conservancies in 2006, the conservancy model was quickly replicated in other areas of the Mara and by 2012 had increased to eight conservancies adjacent to the MMNR (Figure 1).
DRSRS population density estimates are based on transects subdivided into 5 × 5 km2 sampling units, each of which was identified as falling inside or outside a conservancy in Koyiaki (Figure 2).

Only includes those HH involved in the activity (standard errors shown in parenthesis)Figure 3 shows the contribution of different livelihood activities to total annual household income for all households.

Households involved in off-farm activities and household annual income (US$) from off-farm tourism and non-tourism sources

Open in a new tab

aOnly includes those households involved in a particular activityConservancy members versus non-member households
When disaggregating households into conservancy member and non-member households, we find conservancy payments contribute 21% of the total annual income of member households (Figure 4).

For these households, livestock remain far more important and make up the extra contribution; the other activities remain comparable across member and non-member households.Perceived importance of conservancies
Conservancies were ranked as the household’s primary livelihood activity for welfare by only 2% of members, compared with livestock keeping at 74% (Figure 5).
Conservancies were used for livestock grazing throughout the year, but this increased during the dry season (July to October) (Figure 6).
Similar to the conservancies, the heaviest livestock-grazing pressure in the MMNR was found during the dry season (Figure 6).
Figure 7 shows trends in cattle and shoat populations in the Mara ecosystem from 1977 to 2014.

Open in a new tab
Trends in cattle and shoat populations in the Mara ecosystem from 1977 to 2014Livestock trend analysis in relation to conservancies
So what do livestock count data show us about how conservancies are affecting the density and composition of livestock, inside and outside of conservancies? Cattle densities are highly variable and show little discernible change in density over time but with severe drops in density evident during well-known drought periods in 1999 to 2000 and 2009 (Figure 8 on cattle).
Although the density of shoats is equally highly variable, it shows a more obvious trend over time (Figure 8 on shoats), notably a large and sustained increase from 1996 to 2014.

Results can inform better future conservation and tourism investments aimed at maintaining and enhancing pastoral resilience, as well as promoting wildlife conservation.Study area
The Mara comprises the Maasai Mara National Reserve (MMNR) and surrounding conservancies and group ranches (Figure 1).
From an initial two conservancies in 2006, the conservancy model was quickly replicated in other areas of the Mara and by 2012 had increased to eight conservancies adjacent to the MMNR (Figure 1).
DRSRS population density estimates are based on transects subdivided into 5 × 5 km2 sampling units, each of which was identified as falling inside or outside a conservancy in Koyiaki (Figure 2).

Only includes those HH involved in the activity (standard errors shown in parenthesis)Figure 3 shows the contribution of different livelihood activities to total annual household income for all households.

When disaggregating households into conservancy member and non-member households, we find conservancy payments contribute 21% of the total annual income of member households (Figure 4).

For these households, livestock remain far more important and make up the extra contribution; the other activities remain comparable across member and non-member households.Perceived importance of conservancies
Conservancies were ranked as the household’s primary livelihood activity for welfare by only 2% of members, compared with livestock keeping at 74% (Figure 5).
Conservancies were used for livestock grazing throughout the year, but this increased during the dry season (July to October) (Figure 6).
Similar to the conservancies, the heaviest livestock-grazing pressure in the MMNR was found during the dry season (Figure 6).
Figure 7 shows trends in cattle and shoat populations in the Mara ecosystem from 1977 to 2014.

Trends in cattle and shoat populations in the Mara ecosystem from 1977 to 2014Livestock trend analysis in relation to conservancies
So what do livestock count data show us about how conservancies are affecting the density and composition of livestock, inside and outside of conservancies? Cattle densities are highly variable and show little discernible change in density over time but with severe drops in density evident during well-known drought periods in 1999 to 2000 and 2009 (Figure 8 on cattle).
Although the density of shoats is equally highly variable, it shows a more obvious trend over time (Figure 8 on shoats), notably a large and sustained increase from 1996 to 2014.

Livestock trend analysis in relation to conservancies
So what do livestock count data show us about how conservancies are affecting the density and composition of livestock, inside and outside of conservancies? Cattle densities are highly variable and show little discernible change in density over time but with severe drops in density evident during well-known drought periods in 1999 to 2000 and 2009 (Figure 8 on cattle).
Although the density of shoats is equally highly variable, it shows a more obvious trend over time (Figure 8 on shoats), notably a large and sustained increase from 1996 to 2014.

Although the density of shoats is equally highly variable, it shows a more obvious trend over time (Figure 8 on shoats), notably a large and sustained increase from 1996 to 2014.
